subject: Re: [d@DCC] Bill C-59 currently being "debated"
body:
Darwin O'Connor wrote:
> I watched some of it. They talked a lot about how it helps the film 
> production industry, even though it has no effect on Hollywood films 
> produced in Canada. It would have a small effect on Canadian films, but 
> I wouldn't be surprised if the filmmakers are happy to have anyone watch 
> their films, even if they are illegally copied.

   I sent my own MP (and my MP from before I moved a few years ago, who 
I will be meeting with in person next week) a letter.  I sent a similar 
letter (almost identical wording, but as separate letters) to each of 
the 10 MPs that spoke during that "debate".


   I recommend that everyone else also write their members of parliament 
(and the 10 who participated in the debate) as well.  This "debate" may 
be the shape of things to come, with the possibility that the discussion 
of anti-circumvention legislation (the complete abogation of protecting 
the rights of software authors and hardware owners in order to 
theoretically protect the outdated business models of a tiny subset of 
the content industry) being as poor.

My summary of the debate -- the end contains links to the ridings of the 
10 MPs who spoke, and thus links to contact information.
http://www.digital-copyright.ca/node/4011

My letter to MPs
http://www.digital-copyright.ca/node/4010#comment-2436


Darryl Moore,

   I'm curious if you would be willing to author a short sample letter 
that people can send to introduce MPs to the DVD that you sent.  I'm 
thinking of something similar to what I wrote for the GOSLING package.

http://www.digital-copyright.ca/edid/letter3

Here are all the other sample letters we've created thus far:
http://www.digital-copyright.ca/letters

-- 
  Russell McOrmond, Internet Consultant: 
  Please help us tell the Canadian Parliament to protect our property
  rights as owners of Information Technology. Sign the petition!
  http://www.digital-copyright.ca/petition/ict/

  "The government, lobbied by legacy copyright holders and hardware
   manufacturers, can pry my camcorder, computer, home theatre, or
   portable media player from my cold dead hands!"
